properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect

A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow causing widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain followed by possibly heavy snow tonight. A system moving through southern Saskatchewan today is bringing rain showers with a few scattered thunderstorms. As this system progresses further south, the rain will transition to snow along its northern flank this evening and overnight. For southeast portions of Saskatchewan and southwest portions of Manitoba, precipitation should begin as rain this afternoon and then quickly transition to snow before midnight. The entire system exits our region Saturday morning. There is currently a good deal of uncertainty on how fast this transition to snow will occur and with convective elements in the precipitation, there is also uncertainty on total snowfall accumulation. The exact track of the low, the initial melting on warm ground and the capacity of snow to accumulate on higher terrain will all play a role in determining how much snow will accumulate. At this moment, we expect a swath of snow between 5 to 10 cm to fall from Yorkton south to Oxbow and east through Brandon and Pilot Mound. However, because of the uncertainty we cannot rule out locally higher amounts that exceed 10 cm of snow, especially along higher terrain. Snowfall warnings may be issued as this system progresses. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-09T10:41:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-08T18:42:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1607915112.2020

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory until early in the morning. Scattered bands of snow are expected to affect the regions into the morning. Visibility could be quite poor at times locally. Snowfall amounts are expected to be quite variable with some areas receiving a centimetre or less while others could receive up to 5 cm locally. Please consult your local forecast for details on expected snowfall amounts in your region. This will create winter driving conditions in many areas and temperatures dropping below the freezing may may cause slippery conditions. Conditions will improve through the morning as the heaviest snow bands dissipate. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm expected, beginning on Saturday. Locations: Central and northeastern New Brunswick. Maximum wind gusts: northwest to west winds 60 km/h Saturday night into Sunday with up to 80 km/h or higher on the Acadian Peninsula. Time span: Saturday morning until Sunday morning. Remarks: Snow will spread from the southwest toward to the northeast Saturday morning and increase in intensity in the afternoon and evening. As temperatures remain near freezing, snow will likely be heavy and wet. Snow may mix with rain along parts of the Bay of Chaleur coast. Precipitation will taper off to flurries Sunday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-09T10:41:40-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Spring storm over Eastern Quebec this weekend A coastal low pressure system from New England will reach the Gaspé Peninsula on Saturday. Strong winds and significant snowfall amounts are expected with this system. However, there is still some uncertainty as to the track of this low, which could significantly impact snowfall amounts. On Sunday, the combination of strong winds and high tides will be favourable for breaking sea conditions along the coast of the Gaspé Peninsula. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-09T11:37:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-08T19:38:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2492513732.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A late season snowfall in store for some regions of the province. Total snowfall: up to 10 cm for some areas, possibly more especially over the Cape Breton Highlands.. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h, Location: northern and western Nova Scotia. Time span: Saturday night into Sunday. Remarks: Periods of snow and strong winds are expected to develop Saturday evening over western Nova Scotia where westerly winds blow onshore. These conditions are forecast to spread eastward across northern Nova Scotia later Saturday night, reaching the Cape Breton Highlands during the overnight hours. Conditions will improve Sunday morning over western areas of the province, and later in the morning or in the afternoon over eastern regions. Large waves, pounding surf and elevated sea levels are expected. Locations: the Nova Scotia coastline of the Bay of Fundy, including the Minas Basin. Time Span: from 11:00 p.m. Saturday to 3:00 am on Sunday. Remarks: An intensifying low pressure system will pass just north of Nova Scotia on Saturday. This will give storm surge combined with waves approaching the Fundy coast of the province from the west, as well as large spring tides this weekend. The combined effects may cause minor flooding. If the storm track or intensity changes, storm surge warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-09T12:25:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-08T20:26:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2156629861.2020
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Digby County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass, Colchester County - Cobequid Bay, Colchester County North, Hants County, Colchester County - Truro and south, Pictou County, Antigonish County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County

Time span: Saturday afternoon and evening. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels with large waves are expected near the coast. Potential breaking sea conditions and overwash warning issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on May 8, 2020. An intense low pressure system approaching from New England will give strong winds on Sunday over the regions specified below. The combination of these winds and the current run of high-amplitude tides could produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast in the vicinity of the following localities on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Daylight Time). Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2020-05-10, from 03:00 AM to 06:00 AM. Matane: 2020-05-10, from 03:00 AM to 06:00 AM. Sainte-Anne-des-Monts - Grande-Vallee: 2020-05-10, from 03:00 AM to 06:00 AM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-09T11:38:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-08T19:39:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2833312716.2020
Area: Mont-Joli area, Le Bic - Rimouski area, Matane, Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated sea levels are expected. Locations: South to west facing coastlines from Sheet Harbour west into Shelburne County then north into Yarmouth County. Time Span: from 7:00 p.m. to 11:00 pm on Saturday. Remarks: An intensifying low pressure system will pass just north of Nova Scotia on Saturday. This will give storm surge combined with waves approaching the Atlantic coast of the province from the southwest. The waves combined with the storm surge may cause minor flooding. If the storm track or intensity changes, storm surge warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-09T12:37:49-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may destroy crops. Frost is likely again tonight with temperatures dropping to near or below zero. Hazard: Frost and freeze conditions. Timing: Reoccurring nightly through Tuesday. Impact: Frost-sensitive crops and plants could be damaged or killed by frost. Action: Take preventative measures to protect frost-sensitive crops and plants. An extended period of significantly colder than normal temperatures will result in several days of frost and, at times, hard freezes across much of Southern Ontario. These conditions are expected to persist through Tuesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-09T06:12:43-00:00

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Temperatures will drop to near or below the freezing mark overnight tonight. In addition, the relatively cool weather for this time of the year will continue for several more days. As a result, the frost advisory for Southwestern Quebec could be maintained for all nights and mornings through the rest of this week, possibly through Tuesday morning. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected on Saturday. Total snowfall: 5-15 cm or more in some areas. Location: Northwestern and parts of southern New Brunswick. Time span: Saturday morning through Sunday morning. Remarks: A mix of snow and rain is expected to spread across New Brunswick Saturday morning and continue through Saturday night. Forecast guidance indicates that that the greatest snowfall accumulations will likely be over northern and central regions where snowfall warnings have been issued. The snow will taper to flurries on Sunday morning, which will be accompanied by brisk northwesterly winds. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
